B00122HTT0|5.0|This might be Neil Young's best album.<br /><br />I suspect there are reasons it isn't often regarded as such; it was unavailable on CD until 2006, so it wasn't as widely known as the ones that caught the ears of the critics, or won the hearts of the public. And the songs from \\"On the Beach\\" that those of us without record players had heard--\\"Walk On\\" and \\"For The Turnstiles,\\" both on his Greatest-Hits collection, \\"Decade\\"--possibly ended up there because frequent producer David Briggs produced them, and not because they were the best songs on the album. (According to the excellent biography \\"Shakey,\\" a must-read for any fan of Neil's, Briggs was a bit of a control freak, and tended to be dismissive of songs he hadn't had a part in; he produced \\"Decade\\" but only the aforementioned two songs on \\"On The Beach.\\" And this--granted, I'm speculating--might be why other tracks didn't make the cut. And it's a shame, because there are at least three songs here that are better: \\"Revolution Blues\\" and \\"On the Beach\\" and \\"Ambulance Blues.\\")<br /><br />Of course, Neil simply has a pretty wide and varied discography; in a field of albums that are standouts by other artist's standards, it's easy for such a unique album to get left out. Few musicians have dabbled in a wider range of styles; generally speaking, he alternates between charging raging hard rock and whispery singer-songwriter stuff, but he's covered enough ground between and around these poles that it isn't a simple either/or equation. On \\"Rust Never Sleeps,\\" he drew a sharp line down the middle of his musical persona by dividing his album into acoustic and electric sides, making a closing bookend for a decade-plus of prime singer/songwriter rock by inverting the formula of Dylan's \\"Bringing it All Back Home.\\" If those albums are endpoints, though, \\"On the Beach\\" is one of the high points in between.<br /><br />On this, Neil did something much different than he'd later do on the black/white \\"Rust,\\" or on his various other excellent (but somewhat more monochromatic) albums; here he seemingly put more effort into integrating his various tendencies and painting with multiple hues. Unlike, say, the bleak and dark \\"Tonight's the Night,\\" there are loud and bright songs here (\\"Walk On\\"), and clean and harrowing ones (\\"On the Beach\\" and \\"Ambulance Blues.\\") The tunes are full and rich without the sick orange slickness of \\"Harvest,\\" and they're meaningful and deep without the sloppiness of \\"Tonight's the Night.\\" And people rightly laud the pithy insight that \\"It's better to burn out than it is to rust\\" on \\"Rust Never Sleeps,\\" but there's plenty of pith here, as well. \\"I'm deep inside myself, but I'll get out somehow,\\" he laments on \\"Motion Pictures,\\" for instance; although it is a whine, it's one I can always relate to. (The same goes for the title track's complaint that \\"Though my problems are meaningless, that don't make `em go away\\" and the closing track's observation that \\"It's easy to get buried in the past when you try to make a good thing last.\\") And lest I forget--is there a more awesome song than \\"Revolution Blues\\"? Neil's the one who dared to chronicle the dark side of the hippie dream, the drug deals gone bad and the friends ODing, and this song is the darkest of the dark, a prime piece of proto-grunge sung from the perspective of none other than Charles Manson. And yet it never sounds as fake or contrived as it could have been in the hands of a lesser writer; it's a shambling, shimmering piece of funky blues that stays with you long after you stop listening to it.<br /><br />On the surface, it seems like an aberration, this track--edgier and darker than almost anything else on this album. And yet there is something apropos about it, and something whole about \\"On The Beach\\" that makes it a landmark--one often overlooked, and half-buried in the sand, but a landmark all the same--for both the artist and the decade. For it speaks to where the artist and his country-of-residence found themselves in 1974--looking for a little head space, as if wandering amidst sand and surf until the sun and the waves could bleach and fade and bury and wash everything away, all the unfortunate banner headlines and the rusted pieces of the American Dream. \\"On the Beach\\" showed us Neil with a head full of bad memories, staring off into an emptiness that seemed infinite, but it was also a place to put his problems (and ours) in perspective, and to find a fresh start.r a little head space, as if wandering amidst sand and surf until the sun and the waves could bleach and fade and bury and wash everything away, all the unfortunate banner headlines and the rusted pieces of the American Dream. \\"On the Beach\\" showed us Neil with a head full of bad memories, staring off into an emptiness that seemed infinite, but it was also a place to put his problems (and ours) in perspective, and to find a fresh start.
B001QOGYFO|4.0|You always get a potential mixed bag when comics are adapted to the silver screen. Not everything done in a comic can translate to the screen and vice versa. And creative liberties are almost always used in excess, when compared to the actual source material. Fortunately, such is not the case for &#34;Whiteout.&#34; The story revolves around a female US Marshall named Carrie Stetko (very well played by actress Kate Beckinsale), as she is forced to investigate a murder on an Antarctic base, just days before the long six month winter, and a powerful whiteout storm, is about to hit.<br /><br />This dramatic &#34;whodunit&#34; mystery starts off on a slow burn, but yet it never feels like it is dragging. As the body count rises, the puzzle sucks you in, not just about the murders and why they are happening, but about Carrie's own past that has brought her to this desolate wilderness. Tom Skerritt is good as the comforting doctor, while Gabriel Macht is passable as the slick Government agent. But the film almost totally rests on Kate Beckinsale's role. She makes it believable, not only through her no-nonsense attitude on the job, but through the more vulnerable parts, as the painful secret she's been running from is revealed. In some ways she's as cold and dead inside, as the environment surrounding her is outside. You develop a real empathy for her character and it sucks you right into what is happening around her. Beckinsale literally carries the main emotional thrust of the film single-handed, but she does so quite well.<br /><br />The cinematography is also extremely strong. The sweeping landscape shots easily convey the beauty and vast emptiness of the region. The dangers of those who would seek to dwell in such a place feels quite real. There are a few times, though, where the atmosphere of a terrain so hostile to human life isn't necessarily portrayed accurately, but they don't really detract that much from the film, as if you are already invested in Carrie and the mystery, you probably won't even notice them. Also, one of the red herrings on who is behind the killings is hammered on a little too often, which makes you know that person can't be the one, but that is a small quibble in an otherwise nice and taut mystery.<br /><br />Having read the graphic novel the film is based upon, I already knew who is ultimately behind the murders, but it was still a real treat to watch it unfold. For those who haven't read it, I think this film will give you the kind of intelligent thriller fans of this genre of film enjoy. Don't listen to all the haters and give this film a shot. It's actually much better than many are giving it credit for.e mystery, you probably won't even notice them. For those who haven't read it, I think this film will give you the kind of intelligent thriller fans of this genre of film enjoy. Don't listen to all the haters and give this film a shot. It's actually much better than many are giving it credit for.

We live in a world where not too many of us can find the time to write down their thoughts, with a pen and on paper but, again, the Moleskines aren't for everyone. To the extent that there are people who not only love to write but love to write specifically about the movies they watch, the Passions series Film Journal is a notebook dream come true. But, let's examine what one gets.<br /><br />First and foremost this is a Moleskine, and it's very much true to its tradition of look, feel and quality. It comes with the traditional and most useful elastic band, nice cardboard binding that allows it to lie flat when opened without cracking the spine, excellent quality paper, rounded corners, THREE ribbon bookmarks and the 2-pocket mini accordion file inside the back cover.<br /><br />Now, this being a Film Journal, it includes a listing of a few dozen major film festivals, sorted by continent and location, an event planner, personal tabbed pages under half a dozen tabs with preprinted tab stickers to be found inside the accordion file. The main section is, of course, the movie journal. Alphabetically organized, it provides one page per movie with sections for recording the movie's title, country and year, awards won, directors, actors, quotes, notes, opinion and rating. For a movie lover who loves to write, can't get much better than this.<br /><br />I love this notebook for its quality make, its design and for its familiar look and feel. But I am repeating myself. It's a 5-star item without hesitation.

1439102813|5.0|\\"Still Alice\\" is the most disturbing book I have read in many years - and that's the genius of it.  Author Lisa Genova has fashioned a novel about a scholarly woman in her early 50's suffering from early onset Alzheimer's disease, and explores the toll that her disease takes on her marriage, her family, her career, and her sense of self.<br /><br />The subject matter is already sturdy stuff, but Genova ratchets up the poignancy and the heartbreak of Alice Howland's struggle by constantly changing the reader's point of view.  Sometimes we are simply observers, being told a story - but at other times, Genova puts us inside Alice's brain, forcing us to experience her confusion, her fear and her frustration as if we, too, were slowly but surely succumbing to an encroaching onslaught of dementia.  So masterful is Genova's writing that reading the novel almost becomes oppressive.  Walking in Alice's shoes becomes a harrowing - and haunting - experience.<br /><br />I can't in all honesty claim to have 'enjoyed' \\"Still Alice\\" - it's not that kind of book.  But I definitely am enriched with a greater understanding of what Alzheimer's disease is all about, and an even deeper compassion for those who live with the disease, and for those who love and care for them.  I've already passed along my copy to other members of my family who are having the same profound reaction to it that I have described in this review.  Highly recommended to those readers who seek a better understanding of this insidious and epidemic disease.

After 2 years of use, they've finally started to short out in both sides (mixture of static and silence).  But, I find them so comfortable and the perfect headphones for working out that I purchased another two pair (in case they eventually go out of stock and I need another pair).

0452287022|5.0|Girl With A Pearl Earring is based on the famous painting by the same name by Johannes Vermeer. Chevalier brings that mysterious woman who looks out at us from her frame to life and injects her into everyday life in Delft. Griet becomes a maid in the Vermeer household and struggles right from the start to find her place there. The one place where she finds solace is when she is cleaning the studio for the painter. Little does she know that the solace that she finds there and the attention she gets from Johannes makes people in the house become upset. As things get increasingly out of control, Griet must make some decisions that will affect her life and her place in the household.<br /><br />I initially read this book about 5 years ago - and I really didn't remember much when it came to reading it again this time. I think it probably had something to do with the fact that I had to read it for school - and that is never as enjoyable. I feel that this is one of the best art novels around - it sets the bar high for every subsequent novel.<br /><br />One of the things that I found very interesting is how different Vermeer's wife, Catherina, is portrayed in this book compared to how she is portrayed in The Golden Tulip by Rosalind Laker. In both stories a young girl goes to live with the Vermeers (in Pearl Earring as a maid and in Tulip as an apprentice). Catherina doesn't like Griet and goes out of her way to make life difficult for her. But in Tulip she is very kind and welcoming to Francesca. It's amazing how different authors can depict the same person so differently. I think I liked her much better in Tulip.<br /><br />Another aspect that I really enjoyed was how all of Vermeer's famous paintings came to life in this novel. You got to meet all of the people who sat for the paintings and it added a deeper meaning to the works. On her website, Chevalier, has the paintings juxtaposed with lines from the novel.<br /><br />Overall I very much enjoyed this story. Besides learning about the life of the artist and the paintings, I learned about the camara obscura (a box with mirrors that somehow helps the artist see his work better) and how pigments were made. This was my first Chevalier book, but it won't be my last.tist and the paintings, I learned about the camara obscura (a box with mirrors that somehow helps the artist see his work better) and how pigments were made. This was my first Chevalier book, but it won't be my last.

The treble is all the way up, and the bass is all the way down. Some of the guitar solos also seem to have a drastic increase in the already jacked up treble, making for a harsh squeeking noise that actually hurts your ears. It's like listening to AM radio on a small transistor radio with a 2 inch speaker. It really sounds like an awful quality live bootleg, and I'm not talking about the bonus live disc it comes with. The volume of the vocals also fluctuates wildly, and most of \\"Gimmie Danger\\" has no drums, just a hi-hat and cymbals. This is a drastically different mix from the original 1973 bowie mix. At times this recording resembles the screeching sounds heard on albums by Throbbing Gristle. Either listen to the original or the 1997 remastered/remixed version.

B000B5XOQQ|5.0|Saturday afternoons were made for great adventure yarns, and serials dating all the way back to the silent era played upon our love of a rousing good jungle story, filled with danger and the thrill of discovery, with just enough romance thrown in to suggest love sprung from such exciting endeavors. RKO would make the most supreme adventure of all time and in 1933 change the expectations of moviegoers forevermore once the lights dimmed and their logo adorned screens across America. A new bar for adventure was set, and the film which raised it was King Kong. Merian C. Cooper and Ernest B. Shoedsack helmed this fabulous RKO film from an idea by Cooper and Edgar Wallace.<br /><br />King Kong was much more than a girl screaming as a huge ape held her in his palm, just as Fay Wray was much more than a \\"B\\" icon with one great sound film to her credit. She had graced many silent productions, including Coast Patrol, Street of Sin, The Wedding March, and Paramount's last silent, The Four Feathers, where she worked with Merian C. Cooper. She made an easy transition to sound, her lovely presence and vulnerability boosting many early talkies from average to worth watching. Her importance to the success of King Kong is often not given its full due due to the staggering technical achievements behind the camera, often overshadowing everything else. Wray is simply wonderful at the beginning of King Kong, making viewers fall in love with her Ann Darrow long before Kong appears. If this was only an extraordinarily polished jungle adventure, it would be a film classic simply on the basis of Wray's performance and a timeless 1930's sense of style and adventure. With the added element of King Kong, a fearsome beast protective of something too beautiful to allow harm to come to it, it became one of the greatest films ever made.<br /><br />Robert Armstrong is Carl Denham, a filmmaker known for his exciting tales of adventure. A ship bound for a mysterious location only known to Denham to make a film needs only a bit of romance to satisfy the studio. Finding the lovely Ann Darrow about to pass out from hunger during the depression is a stroke of luck for the brash director. Ann is suspicious of Denham's proposal at first, but hunger and his enthusiasm, and his assurance that there are no strings attached, give Ann hope that her luck has changed. Fay Wray is wonderful in these early moments, which often get forgotten amidst the thrilling adventure encountered in the later half of the story. She endears herself to the audience early on and cements our affection for Ann once onboard. Bruce Cabot is excellent as John Driscoll, weary of having a woman onboard but soon falling in love with Anne just as viewers have. Their romance is sweet, filled with the innocent love of the era that has a timeless appeal.<br /><br />It has been breezy fun for the viewer until the ship is west of Sumatra. Denham reveals a map he has obtained in Singapore pinpointing an uncharted island where legends of a high wall and a beast called Kong are said to exist. As they approach Skull Island adventurous fun gives way to fog shrouded waters and jungle drums. The high wall does indeed exist, and after a scrape with natives enamored of Ann they find themselves confronted by a world untouched by time. Great beasts from prehistoric times roam the jungles of the island, Kong the most fearsome of all, ruling his kingdom from a high cliff where he will take Ann. Harrowing action and thrills ensue as Jack tracks his love after Kong disposes of everyone else but Carl to protect his lovely prize. The special effects still offer excitement but it is the story which makes this film such a classic. We are rooting for Jack to rescue Ann just as in the best serials, only this is no serial, but rather a topflight production creating an astounding adventure heretofore unseen in theatres.<br /><br />A gripping escape over a cliff edge will lead to Kong's demise when he follows Ann and is capturedby Carl. Billed as the Eighth Wonder of the World, the flash of cameras perceived by Kong as an attack on his Ann creates chaos in the streets when he breaks free, leading to perhaps the most famous ending in film history. High above the New York skyline, atop the Empire State Building, Ann will find herself in the arms of the man who loves her when Kong faces down dangers he never had in the jungle. It is both romantic and bittersweet. Max Steiner's score, a screenplay by James Ashmore Creelman and Ruth Rose which perfectly balances romance and adventure, and sterling photography from Eddie Linden, Veronica Walker, and J.C. Taylor make this a memorable experience.<br /><br />Though Fay Wray is terrific in this film, it is a shame that many viewers only know her from King Kong. Born in Canada but raised in the United States, she was a big supporter of events held at the Empire State Building over her lifetime, and after her passing, the lights of that landmark were dimmed for fifteen minutes in her memory. King Kong is perfect viewing for a lazy Saturday and if you haven't seen it in some time, or perhaps never seen it, it is much more than you might have imagined. A lovely way to remember Fay Wray.h Wonder of the World, the flash of cameras perceived by Kong as an attack on his Ann creates chaos in the streets when he breaks free, leading to perhaps the most famous ending in film history. High above the New York skyline, atop the Empire State Building, Ann will find herself in the arms of the man who loves her when Kong faces down dangers he never had in the jungle. It is both romantic and bittersweet. Max Steiner's score, a screenplay by James Ashmore Creelman and Ruth Rose which perfectly balances romance and adventure, and sterling photography from Eddie Linden, Veronica Walker, and J.C. Taylor make this a memorable experience.      Though Fay Wray is terrific in this film, it is a shame that many viewers only know her from King Kong. Born in Canada but raised in the United States, she was a big supporter of events held at the Empire State Building over her lifetime, and after her passing, the lights of that landmark were dimmed for fifteen minutes in her memory. King Kong is perfect viewing for a lazy Saturday and if you haven't seen it in some time, or perhaps never seen it, it is much more than you might have imagined. A lovely way to remember Fay Wray.

1584282584|5.0|As a guy who picked up photography only a few years ago, I have been looking to improve my ability to improve my exposures by looking for various books and articles on the net. I never needed flash when my daughter couldn't move around much. Put the camera on a tripod and use a remote to fire away in automatic mode. No problem! But, now she is a bounding 3 year old and indoor pics required me to use a flash. The pop-up was useless for the most part since it did not give me the soft lighting and I am too lazy to get the flash off the camera and chase my daughter around with a couple softboxes and lightstands waiting for that perfect moment. Also, I did not want her eyes glowing every time I used the flash pointing directly at her. So I was stuck on the question of \\"How can I use a flash on a camera only and get soft lighting and better pictures without blinding my child in the process?\\"    Once I hit Neil's website I stopped searching for an answer. He clearly explains how a flash works, how to use his black snoot to direct and model the light and most importantly on how to mix ambient light and flash. Using the built in technology like E-TTL and hence improving speed of use while understanding light characteristics has been immensely helpful to getting better pictures.    He has distilled all those thoughts into a very informative book. It's short, to the point, very descriptive and informative with the requisite number of images to make the point. Very highly recommended by me.

B002VPE1B6|5.0|I've only watched the blu-ray version twice, but it is really incredible.  I have never seen any HD to compare with this one.  The movie itself is a work of art, with an incredible level of creativity and beautiful design/ornamentation to stretch anyone's imagination.  The 3-D effect, through parallax (humans perceive 3-D by both binocular vision, for near objects, and parallax, for more distant objects)is the best I have seen.  The theme is also highly relevant to our times.  The expressivity of the actors is beyond comparison, certainly real, and enhanced by the technology used to produce this.  I really look forward to an expanded version of this blu-ray in the future, if one is forthcoming.  I have heard a popular story line related to the lack of an original story or character development in this, and it is just gibberish.  I can see how the film would be viewed as a threat to traditional Hollywood filmmaking, however.  I have seen 'Hurt Locker' that won the Academy Award for best picture, and it is a good film.  The single theme and unidimensional character of that movie was simply this:  obsession with dangerous work.  In contrast, Avatar has a great deal to say about native cultures that are close to nature (e.g., stone age cultures) in general, exploitation of resources by technology-driven societies, and the mystery of life itself.  It will make you think about the mystery of incarnation.  This is a deeply thoughtful production, a fact that should not be missed as you follow the carefully written action/adventure story line.  The theme, and the artwork, bear a signature that is unique in the history of filmmaking.  Also, if you don't already have a blu-ray, DVD-upconvert player, this is the best reason to get one now.

0553381687|5.0|This is a review of the Song of Ice and Fire series, not just A Game of Thrones. Four books have been released so far--A Game of Thrones, A Clash of Kings, A Storm of Swords, and A Feast for Crows. The fifth, A Dance with Dragons, is forthcoming, and two more are projected after that. You'll probably be working your way through Martin's books for a while, so I'll address the good points and you can decide whether to dive in.<br /><br />  First of all, what should be the most important part of any fiction: the characters. One of my old writing professors got shot down bad when someone asked, \\"Couldn't you pick a more interesting set of characters to endlessly explore?\\" Fortunately, Martin doesn't have that problem. His characters are an intensely gritty bunch. Some are less prepared to deal with the hard world than others, just like in real life. They get their romantic illusions shattered, though their starry-eyedness makes you half-enjoy the shattering. I think Martin does, too. Every player in the game goes through some kind of development; the \\"good\\" guys have major flaws and the \\"bad\\" guys have qualities we'd all love to possess. You may find yourself rooting for folks you despise and wanting to slap characters who are supposed to be sympathetic. For example, one character is portrayed as a devoted mother and wife, a fierce she-wolf of a woman. However, after a while you start to think her \\"devotion\\" is tantamount to mental illness. She seems in denial of a large part of life--the part having to do with death. This drives her, inexorably, to her fate, which I'll leave for you to discover. Just remember Martin is big on changes in perspective; \\"obvious\\" villains may be heroes later, and vice versa.<br /><br />  The story these people snarl and fight to bring about is addictive and original. You'll be relieved to see Martin doesn't borrow anything from Tolkien. His historical antecedents are there for all to see: the Wars of the Roses and the aftermath of Rome, for starters. However, he also brings a ton of material to the table. From the ruined castle in the depths of a humid pine forest, to the haunted hill where a stunted old spaewife meets with outlaws, every place has its history. This makes for an incredibly rich, immersive literary experience. You'll encounter folks from the highest point in society to the lowest: from knights and lords bickering about marriage contracts to strolling players looking for a bed and someone to warm it. Peasants, whores, mercenaries, scholars...no aspect of Dark Ages life is ignored. The much-touted \\"intrigue\\" doesn't come across as annoying or stupid, and Martin describes a range of experiences so vast you could compare him to Chaucer. Magic is infrequent, and thus keeps its potency. Examples: a type of steel from Old Valyria that everybody covets for its preternatural sharpness; medieval grimoire gibberish that doesn't work in Martin's world any more than the real one; and bloody sorcery that takes more from the user than it offers.<br /><br />  And now for the sex. There's a lot of it. Much of it involves violence, and women are almost invariably the targets. Martin doesn't shy away from some sordid taboo subjects, although the real-world historical precedents are here just as they are everywhere else. To be fair, the inclusion of the rough stuff is realistic enough given the setting and characters. However, it's also fair enough to warn you of it.<br /><br />  The flaws don't detract much from the overall experience, I find. Sometimes Martin has characters zip about the landscape a little too conveniently, while other journeys are hell on wheels. People in distant locales communicate with each other by means of trained ravens. These are some smart birds that never seem to get lost or shot down. They make you wonder. Finally, there was a scene in A Feast for Crows that made me question how much these medieval savages could know about Leeuwenhoekian microbiology (don't ask).<br /><br />I was surprised at how much I liked these books. Martin does a fantastic job of characterization, and importantly, his fictional world doesn't give the impression that it exists as nothing more than a vehicle for prophecies and thinly disguised Ring-quests. This is what I can't stand about most fantasy fiction. Thankfully, though, Martin takes great pains to keep his setting low, dirty, and credible while maintaining the fantastic elements. You'll read, you'll sympathize, and hopefully, you'll believe and get something out of it.how much I liked these books. Martin does a fantastic job of characterization, and importantly, his fictional world doesn't give the impression that it exists as nothing more than a vehicle for prophecies and thinly disguised Ring-quests. This is what I can't stand about most fantasy fiction. Thankfully, though, Martin takes great pains to keep his setting low, dirty, and credible while maintaining the fantastic elements. You'll read, you'll sympathize, and hopefully, you'll believe and get something out of it.
B001YYQ9SS|4.0|This review is based on the assumption that the reader has both played FF:7 and has seen the original Advent Children. If not, well, don't blame me if I lose you somewheres~~<br /><br />Having been a big fan of the original release, it was all but decided that when I got my PS3, adding this movie to the archives was a requisite. However, as is the case when I meet an upscaled movie, show, or whatever, I tend to whip out the fine-toothed comb and pick it to pieces, either completely shredding said content, or finding completely new aspects to magnify. In Advent Children: Complete's (further abbreviated as AC:C) case, I met with a compromise. The bonus content, as well as the added/edited scenes, counterbalanced most of the issues that arose in the conversion, as well as the translations, which will be expounded upon in the following paragraphs.<br /><br />First, the likes/loves of AC:C. Where to start except for the most obvious; the fact that it's Blu-Ray. And Blu-Ray means High-Def scaling. As I love to say, everything looks better in Blu-Ray, and AC:C is indeed no exception. The added scenes are all redone to match 1080p dimensions, and the original content is all upscaled to fit. Where the original looked good on a standard definition TV, Complete retains that ability with HD-TVs. And if that wasn't enough to sate any appetite, Nobuo Uematsu (whose fame as one of the gods of video game music should be well-known to most, if not all) redid a majority of the soundtrack to compensate for new and edited scenes, as well as personal tweaks for the new version. And I'd be damned (can I even say that?) to say it's anything less than spectacular. However, the most pleasing change was a constant, in that the ending still remained Calling by Himuro Kyousuke, a song which I still love, but with the added bonus of a quick story scroll during said credit roll. The biggest section of this paragraph, however, goes to the story changes. With almost a half an hour of new content alone, AC:C takes the story of Advent Children even deeper. Many circumstances surrounding the Geostigma, as well as character's pasts and events pertaining, have further explanation. Not to mention, extended battle scenes, visible wounds/blood (a HUGE plus in my books, irked the daylights out of me in the first one), and overall more movie to enjoy. I won't spoil anything major here, as this review may actually assist someone in their purchase (never know!), but I was quite pleased with Reno and Rude's extended scene times, as well as the extended backstory with Cloud and Zack (for those of us who never cared enough for the FF:7 prequel they released). And on a tangent, concerning all these new scenes is a new dialogue, which of course, requires translation. And for once in my long and somewhat illustrious anime-viewing career, the company hired for the translation and subtitles did not make me want to rip hair, pull nails, rend flesh, gnash teeth, etc. I don't speak much in the way of Japanese, but I do have a decent understanding of it, and complete and utter misinterpretations, or outright topic shifts (they have happened!) will irk me to no end. Advent Children's original translation was subpar at best, by my standards. AC:C's translation was better than good, but not quite great. There were a few lines that would have been better in straight translations (Black sheep in happy flock = traitor?), but compared to the original, which, for some reason, made Cid to be some kind of cowboy (I still seek the villain responsible), AC:C is far and away an improvement. All in all, this is a fine example of what Director's Cuts should be made of.<br /><br />Naturally, no review of mine is ever complete without me having some kind of gripe. In AC:C's case, there weren't many, but they were major to be sure. The biggest one is also the most glaringly obvious. The original movie was blatantly upscaled. And by blatantly, I mean to the point that (for those who have the originaland have watched it enough to remember scenes) certain parts are almost pixelated in detail. For a discerning eye such as mine, this can be rather painful to deal with, even more so because the added scenes, by contrast, are scaled to fit widescreen dimensions. Granted, I'm sure I come off as being trivial about pointless details, but to each their own. The next gripe pertains to the upscaling which, while not being involved in it, was a part of it, and that is the scene editings for blood, dirt, grime, and, to put it simply, looking like they did stuff. I welcome the change, but at the same time, I loathe it, for two reasons. One, just splashing mud color in random places on clothing DOES NOT add any realism, just like putting circular dots in a row does not make a rectangle. Two, it's going to look bad when you apply an edit in High-Def format to something still in Standard Definition. Is it horribly noticeable? Not really, unless you're looking, actively or passively, for such things. Will you see it though? You bet. And my final gripe has to deal with some of the extended scenes. Some of them, and by some I mean about two to three, made me wonder \\"Why in God's name is this here?\\" Case and point example (if you're concerned about spoilers in any way, shape, or form, skip the following and the next two sentences! Look for the next parentheses to continue.); when Denzel knocks the cap off the hydrant. Is spinning a pipe around above your head really necessary to knock that cap off? Couldn't you have just hacked at it a couple more times instead of thinking that twirling a pipe above your head would have ANY impact on your physical strength? (End minor spoiler) It's a scene that just bothers and annoys me to no end (tl;dr - IMADBRO), but this is not a perfect world that revolves around yours truly, and I must make do with such things.<br /><br />The Final Word.<br /> For those who managed to make it through that, congrats, because your reward is probably the only thing you were looking for in the first place, my overall opinion. Well, that's assuming my opinion actually mattered to anyone, but let's not be moody and depressing, right? Overall, FF:7 AC:C was and is a worthy movie for those who have watched the original, wanted to watch the original, or even have remotely delved into the Final Fantasy universe. Granted, playing the game provides a greater clarification of events, but it's not absolutely necessary. My final grade is 4 stars out of 5. If you wish to see the grading scale, continue reading. If not, well, if you're thinking about purchasing this for your collection, or anyone you know who might be interested, you won't be doing them wrong.<br /><br />--Grading Scale--<br />Story: 5<br />Picture: 3<br />Actors/Voices: 5 (JP)/ 4 (EN)<br />Music: 5<br />Translation: 4<br />Value: 4<br />-----------------<br />26 of 30 available<br />or<br />4.3 of 5ugh to remember scenes) certain parts are almost pixelated in detail. B0026PA05M|4.0|Wow.  Great album.  It's unfortunate that with the internet so prevalent nowadays, it takes me longer to find good music like this than it did in 1982 with MTV and rock radio. Strong highs and soft lows make great rock.  They've re-embraced the guitar solo as well, which you seldom see nowadays. Most rock produced since 1996 is just too flat from start to finish to be considered anything more than \\"ok\\" background noise with a competent but mostly vanilla lead singer.  The thing that really sealed the deal for me was the live acoustic performance I looked up on Youtube. They sound like a band playing their music, well, not a band \\"trying\\" to play their music, poorly, which is all too rare in this day in age.  This is a solid four star album, I'd give it five, but I reserve five stars for albums that \\"transcend\\", true past and future classics with near infinite replay value, such as: (GnR - Appetite for Destruction, Heart - The Road Home, The Zeppelin boxed set, Ozzy's Randy Rhoads Tribute Album, etc.). B0037W68F4|4.0|Well this is interesting, the fans are divided based on the posts here. From my perspective, I give this four stars, good, not great. It is a mash up of different 60's bands like The Beach Boys, The Beatles, The Kinks, The Rolling Stones, The Moody Blues, with a dash of Yes in places. This is modern day 60's of course. Now, you will either like that or not. I like it. I liked their first album too.<br /><br />There's only nine tracks, and that's fine by me. It reminds me of all the great 70's and 80's albums that were short and to the point before the self-indulgent 90's arrived and whiny music became the rage. There are nine tracks, but one is an instrumental, the weakest song of the lot. \\"Lady Da Da's Nightmare\\" could have been left as a b-side, and it wouldn't have been missed.<br /><br />This leaves eight tracks, all good, but none that would qualify as radio-friendly, which is also fine by me. I really liked \\"It's Working\\" and \\"Song For Dan Treacy\\". Two stomping openers to introduce to where the band wants to go this time. This is followed by \\"Someone's Missing\\" with it's Marvin Gaye breakdown at the end. \\"Flash Delirium\\", the unofficial first 'single' if you want to call it that, is also good. \\"I Found A Whistle\\" is very similar, I think, to their \\"The Youth\\" from their last album. Then comes this 12 minute opus \\"Siberian Breaks\\". Now, you are either going to suck this down or spit it out. Already being a fan of progressive rock such as Yes, King Crimson, ELP, Genesis and Rush, I enjoyed it, even right down to all the different segments within (a page torn right out of the Yes songbook). \\"Brian Eno\\" was an interesting choice and rather humorous especially if you are familiar with who he is, who he has produced, and what kind of music he has made on his own. \\"Congratulations\\" is a good song to end the album.<br /><br />So what's the fuss? This album isn't all that different from their debut. Their debut mashed up different musical genres, but this is more 1960's in its approach and feel with some 1970's prog rock thrown in for good measure. Someone said this isn't original, and maybe that's true, but I can't think of who else is willing to take these risks these days (though MGMT does share styles with Animal Collective and Surfer Blood).<br /><br />Four stars for good music. Four stars also for their debut album, which, to be fair, was slightly better than this, their sophomore album, but not by much. I still think they show promise, and with Brian Eno producing their next album, who knows where they could go, right?el with some 1970's prog rock thrown in for good measure. Someone said this isn't original, and maybe that's true, but I can't think of who else is willing to take these risks these days (though MGMT does share styles with Animal Collective and Surfer Blood). Like the rest of CD1, it's insanely over produced and there's not one moment's respite from her horrible voice. She'll sing the chorus, but as she does so, 'another' Christina bellows and screeches gibberish over the top of it! It's like one of her isn't enough! Same thing with any kind of instumental break, there she is again, honking, cooing, just making needless NOISE. She can't bear to be silent for a second.<br /><br />The low point of, well, all time probably, is 'Thank You', a five minute non-song in which Aggie actually shuts up for a couple of minutes while scores of demented, sorry, devoted fans tell her how great she is and 'thank' her endlessly! You get the feeling Aggie would love to join in and thank herself but does manage to restrain herself. Total insanity, or egomania. I can't decide.<br /><br />CD2, the '20's, 30's and 40's' one is quieter, but still awful. It's completely bereft of any kind of memorable material and is perhaps the moment 'Xtina' went insane. You'd have to totally deluded to think this kind of rubbish passes as artistry. One track, 'Save Me From Myself' (a cry for help?!), has Aggie just singing the song simply and maybe showing  how good she could be if someone would have the guts to tell her to tone it down once in a while. Sadly, it's not all good news as the song is absolute cr%p!<br /><br />There were no other hits from 'Back To Basics' and Xtina soon slunk away to lick her wounds before returning a couple of years later with a best of album that was incredibly light on actual popular songs.<br /><br />As I write, Aggie is set to return in a month with her new opus, 'Bionic'. The signs aren't good. The first single, the hideous 'Not Myself Tonight', is the same old noisy, tuneless, oversung crud and would happily fit in on CD1 of BTB. The video is a blatant Lady Ga Ga/Madonna rip off with Xtina reinventing herself as, yes, you guessed it, a tired old scrubber who strips off a lot! Must have took her ages to think that one up!to lick her wounds before returning a couple of years later with a best of album that was incredibly light on actual popular songs. B002N1AEN2|5.0|From its very beginning, the overall mood of The xx's debut release escorts the listener down a rainy highway, and its desolate atmospheres deepen the impact of its sometimes poignant lyrics.  The catchy minimalism of \\"xx\\" has made The xx the \\"new cool thing\\" in some circles, and I suspect that right now, bittersweet breakups and intimate moments between many, many couples are occurring with \\"xx\\" as their soundtrack.  Despite their indie hype, this increased visibility is warranted.  \\"xx\\" is a welcome reprieve from the explicitly nostalgic turn that currently seems to be all the rage.<br /><br />The xx are not virtuosos in the classic sense.  Bassist/singer Oliver Sim, however, plays bass and sings expressively with seemingly little effort; a task that takes no small amount of musicianship.  Along with guitarist and singer Romy Madley Croft, they have a sexy synergy that makes \\"xx\\" simultaneously masculine and feminine.  Couples with a shared interest in addictively singable tunes and starry atmospheres will most likely find lots of common ground.<br /><br />I would say that the atmosphere on \\"xx\\" is dreamy, but not hallucinogenic.  There are times when The xx dips into Pink Floyd territory, but there is in no way a longing for psychedelia.  Instead, perhaps the reverby soundscapes of mid-period Cure is the most appropriate comparison, while the loose, unassuming guitar seems to recall Lou Reed.  In total, this atmosphere, like many albums that feature simple, reverb-laden guitar, recalls the dark beauty of Angelo Badalamenti's soundtrack for \\"Twin Peaks.\\"<br /><br />The entire album is pretty consistent, so if you have heard a little of their work, the rest of the album will pay off.  Suggesting specific tracks for the uninitiated is a little difficult, but the song that piqued my interest in The xx was \\"Crystalized.\\"  That song pretty much sums up their work as well as any.  The lyrics to \\"Crystalized\\" describe a desire for intimacy that is tempered by a frustrated alienation.  Both Croft and Sims sing a unique verse separately, but then simultaneously sing these verses on top of each other, as if to speak so loudly as to not hear.  This is the sort of subtle emotional tension that pervades \\"xx\\" as w whole.<br /><br />THE LOWDOWN: The xx are wonderfully minimal, and certainly write catchy tunes, but beyond that, \\"xx\\" is an album that can be listened to and appreciated on multiple levels.  On one level, it is melodic and accessible enough to invite the listener to sing along.  It also, however, has the capability to provide a \\"still moment\\" in a hyperactive day, in which the listener can look out a window into a grayer world that is somehow more vivid.ft and Sims sing a unique verse separately, but then simultaneously sing these verses on top of each other, as if to speak so loudly as to not hear.  This is the sort of subtle emotional tension that pervades \\"xx\\" as w whole.    THE LOWDOWN: The xx are wonderfully minimal, and certainly write catchy tunes, but beyond that, \\"xx\\" is an album that can be listened to and appreciated on multiple levels.  On one level, it is melodic and accessible enough to invite the listener to sing along.  It also, however, has the capability to provide a \\"still moment\\" in a hyperactive day, in which the listener can look out a window into a grayer world that is somehow more vivid.

Listen to Jimi Hendrix, Robin Trower, and Tony McPhee of the Groundhogs... these guys played and played, wrote some interesting lyrics, and sang while playing [while not singing on his \\"hits\\", Trower has begun singing several of his more recent songs, both in the studio and in concert].    Emotion and Commotion falls far short of what Jeff Beck is capable of and has done in the past.  If he doesn't write lyrics and won't sing, then he has to play his guitar with great distinction, such as Joe Satriani or Steve Vai.  Beck's new album is very disappointing. 0143035711|5.0|It's hard to imagine a more powerful, or insightful \\"pilot's eye\\" non-fiction book about the helicopter war in Vietnam, than Robert Mason's Chickenhawk. Everyone has something to learn about the war, and its effects on the soldiers who fought there, from this seminal work. Easily the definitive first-hand narrative on the subject, Mason's empathetic, coming-of-age perspective, witnesses his cowardice (chicken) and courage (hawk) in combat. His story is impossible to put down, honest, and sometimes humorous. The tragedy, and horror of human conflict, are written indelibly, in this readable tale, that puts the sound of thudding rotor blades in your ears, the gritty taste of Pleiku dust in your mouth, and leaves the vision of graceful, burning, machine gun tracers, coming out of the jungle at night, etched forever in your memory.

1440469563|5.0|I've read four Jane Austen novels in rapid succession, having been rapidly ensnared by [[ASIN:0375757422 Emma (Modern Library Classics)]], and avidly seeking more of this fabulous writer whose greatness I was amazed to have only just discovered. (The others were [[ASIN:1451539290 Pride And Prejudice]], and [[ASIN:1440468397 Persuasion]]<br />  As with all the great classics found on Amazon, many readers have already offered excellent reviews.  In these cases, I have felt little need to add my own, unless I feel I have something new to offer.  In the case of Sense and Sensibility, I do indeed believe the need to offer my view, to do this book what I believe is better justice! Here's why:<br />Many reviewers profess what is apparently the party line on Austen's works-- that while they \\"love this book and give it 5 stars\\", they (feel obliged to) then damn it with faint praise by adding \\"EVEN if it is one of her a. earliest, b. \\"not as poslished\\", c. \\"not as complex\\", or d. \\"not as funny, well-written,... etc. etc.\\"<br />  I must take issue!<br />1. Even if any or all of the above are so, (which I could waste many lines on disputing, to no useful purpose), why would any of these attributes of supposed inferiority be relevant to enjoying this book for itself?  They themselves belie such relevance by noting their own great pleasure in reading THIS Jane Austen book.  If indeed JA is a brilliant master novelist (no contest here), any and all her books is worth reading for its own sake, as each of them, and as no doubt JA herself would hope.  The only reason to compare the finer distinctions among them would be to recommend which of her books one should read IF one could only read one or two.  Indeed, not a one reviewer would I dare say recommend any such thing!  Sense and Sensibility, as does each of the other 3 JAs I've read, has its own unique treasures to yield to the reader, and it is for these that each must be appreciated and each and all read.<br />2. Sense and Sensibility is a great analysis and example of the power of FILIAL love to transform a person for the better, and thereby to enable her to gain happiness. In my view, the interest in placing the two \\"opposing\\" virtues of Sense and Sensibility in each of the two sisters, Elinor and Marianne, is not simply to showcase the benefits and pitfalls the key virtue confers to the holder, but, much more illuminatingly, the value of the love between the two to cause the other to grow into a woman who can have BOTH in proper degree.  Indeed, the book's ending will prove this!<br />3. In Sense and Sensibility, there are many themes developed extensively which are not a focus of the three others I read, aside from #2. One is demonstrated in the character and actions of Lucy, initially presented as an almost deceptively minor character. (I wont say more, but this alone is a real gem worth reading the book for.)  Another is the evolution of the sisters' regard for a number of important characters in the book. Each of these is developed and explained beautifully--the regard for Willoughby, for Mrs. Jennings, for Captain Brandon, Edward. These changes are effected not only by and within each sister, but by and within several other characters...with most edifying effects for the education not only the protagonists, but for me!<br />4.  Finally, Sense and Sensibility features key themes also showcased in the other three books, e.g., the power of real love to change one's character--one's pride and or prejudices for example (in that named book!), or the well-known to all (but beautifully illustrated examples of) wisdom, that how one reacts to love and the obstacles it creates or are created in its way, depends on character, and luck...but the love itself rarely is under one's control!  And yet, of course, since each book's treatment of this theme is unique and reveals a host of unique vicissitudes it can involve, S and S and each of the others is well-worth the reward of the unique discoveries it offers the reader.<br />I need say no more, and direct the reader to start \\"clicking\\" all four of the above into your carts!es it offers the reader.<br />I need say no more, and direct the reader to start \\"clicking\\" all four of the above into your carts!

B00005221L|5.0|[[ASIN:B000244EMO Predator]] is a true sci-fi classic. Like the [[ASIN:B0000VCZK2 Alien Quadrilogy (Alien/ Aliens /Alien 3 /Alien Resurrection)]], a powerful alien creature slaughters humans like cattle.     What makes [[ASIN:B000244EMO Predator]] so great - and what more recent copycats lack - is a great cast of characters and dramatic scenes. Far from just being cannon fodder, you actually start to like Dillon and Blane and the rest. I'll never forget the scene when Dillon becomes so nervous he breaks his razor while shaving - what a great way to add tension to the scene. Of course, Arnold Schwarzenegger does a great job of being both tough and in control.     Remarkably, for a film over 23 years old, the special effects don't seem dated at all. That's another great thing about the way the movie was made - rather than stuffing it with computer-generated graphics, the filmmakers used the technology they had in creative ways to accomplish what they needed. The result is more subtle and interesting, including not knowing what the Predator looks like until the end rather than shooting dozens of closeup shots of CG Predators..    If you haven't seen it, definitely check it out. Unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be a high quality blu-ray version out yet, but the regular DVD is just fine.     Interesting sidenote: two of the actors in this film, Schwarzenegger and Jesse Venture, later become governors. That could only happen with a quality movie!

0385523386|1.0|I found out about this book through a popular woman's magazine and I was so interested in it that I paid full cover price. I wish I had not. I am interested in reading about a woman who has had this kind of life changing experience, even if it was not a more \\"hard time\\" kind of experience. In some ways, Kerman exposes the minimum security prison's inability to provide some education and proper meals for the inmates. She illustrates the bonds that can form between women of different backgrounds that are brought together by circumstance. I believe, however, that this book would benefit from some editing and organization in the writing style. I hope I can finish it, but I will not be keeping it on my self for a re-read at a later time.

0307408833|4.0|I am not an experienced baker, not do I have a gluten allergy. Simply put, I just love this bakery and wanted to try to recreate at home. Due to the abundance of negative reviews, I first checked out this book from my local library. I made a few desserts (the cookie sandwiches, vanilla frosting, and cupcakes). I did not have success with the frosting, but the cookies and cupcakes were fairly straight forward and simple to make. That said, I emailed the bakery about the frosting and they promptly replied with some recommendations. Then, I had success (I added more soy milk powder and oil, then pulsed in the food processor until creamy and the consistency I wanted). Then, my husband bought me the cookbook! I am thrilled to own it and bake from it quite frequently.<br /><br />My thoughts on the cookbook layout, ingredients, and recipes:<br /><br />Cookbook layout: This book is gorgeous and the layout is so fresh and fun. It's a really beautiful book, as others have noted. Make sure you read the entire book before you begin. Erin makes a lot of helpful notes throughout, as well as provides ingredient explanations and tips. Also, see the actual website for more cookbook help.<br /><br />Ingredients: Yes, the items you need are much more expensive than cheap, bleached white flour and Crisco. I eat both gluten-free and flour-based desserts and sweets, and I always buy the best ingredients available. I strongly believe in eating only the very best food, so why put something in your body that is processed, cheap, and full of additives? That said, these ingredients are not really any more pricey than non-gluten-free ingredients. The coconut oil should be virgin and can be found in small jars at Whole Foods (in fact, I found EVERYTHING I need at Whole Foods in one shopping trip). It's about $10 a jar and some recipes use the entire jar (the frosting and cookies or cupcakes) but for the most part the jar will make 3 or 4 desserts. I buy a few at a time and store it, and usually Whole Foods has their 365 brand on sale for $6.99 a jar. You must also melt the oil before use; I microwave mine in the jar and it's fine. You're also supposed to use the unscented variety, but I can't seem to find that so I just use what WF has and it's fine.<br /><br />Also, the flours get a lot of use out of them, even if they are a bit more pricey. Try to find the Bob's Red Mill large bag of the Baking Mix- it will save money and time because you will use that mix quite often. I don't have a problem with it's taste; I actually think the mix is delicious. My favorite is the spelt flour though and the entire section on scones and biscuits. Yum! Thumb through the book and make a list of all the flours needed, that way you can purchase all at once and store them in your freezer. Bob's Red Mill makes everything you will need, except the spelt of course. I use Arrowhead Mills Whole Grain Spelt and it's inexpensive. The Xanathan gum is the only pricey one (at $11 a bag at WF) but you only use a 1/4-1 teaspoon per recipe.<br /><br />Another recommendation is the get to know the ingredients before you begin. It took me a few recipes to become acclimated with the flours and oil, but now I understand how they fit into each recipe, just as I know about the purpose of flour, sugar, butter and eggs. If you are able to understand these ingredients, you will be able to make modifications when a recipe doesn't turn out as planned.<br /><br />Lastly, I use regualr sugar- the Baker's fine sugar. It works out well for me and it happens that I have a large container at home. So, I didn't spend more money on the evaporated cane juice, which is essentially the same thing (only not as processed).<br /><br />Recipes: My only negative review of this book is that a lot of the recipes don't turn out perfectly on the first try. After I made my favorites (cookies, cupcakes, scones, biscuits, cornbread, and the apple loaf) I made them a second time and they turned out much better. I had to change ingredient amounts, baking times, and pan sizes. I feel like Erin did not test her recipes in a normal kitchen with normal size pans, thus the discrepancy in the baking times. The loaves work best when made in two pans (or muffin tins) and I don't really follow her baking times because mine always take longer. However, I do think she did a great job in writing her first cookbook. I'm sure her second is bound to be better.<br /><br />Good luck to everyone. I really recommend the scones; they are easy to make and terribly delicious.<br /><br />UPDATE: I add 1/3 cup more flour to EACH of Erin's loaf recipes. For some reason, mine all fall and stay gooey despite long stays in the oven (one cooked for over an hour to no avail). So, I checked the babycakes website for cookbook help and it's noted to add more flour. I add the extra flour no matter what- I prefer a drier crumb and plumper loaf.es. I feel like Erin did not test her recipes in a normal kitchen with normal size pans, thus the discrepancy in the baking times. The loaves work best when made in two pans (or muffin tins) and I don't really follow her baking times because mine always take longer. However, I do think she did a great job in writing her first cookbook. I'm sure her second is bound to be better.     Good luck to everyone. I really recommend the scones; they are easy to make and terribly delicious.    UPDATE: I add 1/3 cup more flour to EACH of Erin's loaf recipes. For some reason, mine all fall and stay gooey despite long stays in the oven (one cooked for over an hour to no avail). So, I checked the babycakes website for cookbook help and it's noted to add more flour. I add the extra flour no matter what- I prefer a drier crumb and plumper loaf.

0393072231|4.0|The \\"Big Short\\" is a fast-paced account focusing on a few traders leading up to the financial meltdown of 2008.  It is a riveting, page-turner that I read in one sitting.  As thoughtful entertainment, it completely succeeds.<br /><br />Using the stories of a few traders makes an excellent way to grip the reader and illustrate the causes of the meltdown.  Since Lewis is a superb writer, he manages to make the murky world of CDO's and CDS's relatively understandable - and if not transparent at least make visible the reasons for their opacity.  Many of the larger causes and issues with the current financial system get mentioned in passing in this book, but the \\"big picture\\" is never presented.<br /><br />In the last chapter Lewis brings the story back to his thesis that the root cause lies in the banking houses having gone public.  This is as \\"macro\\" as he gets.  However, this is a disappointing and simplified analysis.  In my view, too many companies going public has been bad for the economy, because their focus becomes too short-term.  However, this is part of a bigger piece.  As a society we've been engaged in mass wishful thinking fostered by economists and politicians that the magical market will always correct itself without government intervention.  We dismantled our regulatory framework and allowed a few greedy people to loot our wealth.  This is not just limited to banking, but pervades the economy.  We've allowed wealth to concentrate in the hands of a few individuals to the harm of the rest of us.  Our politicians have used the rhetoric of \\"freedom\\" to persuade people to vote against their own economic self-interest.<br /><br />The Big Short is well worth reading and a good way to get an understanding of the financial instruments involved in the crisis for those who cannot or will not understand arcane details of finance.  From the microeconomic perspective of the subprime meltdown, it is very informative.  However, this book provides no meaningful macroeconomic or political perspective.pective.
1400052173|5.0|\\"The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks\\" by Rebecca Skloot is a tough book to classify.  While it covers issues of science and cultural studies, at its heart it is the simple story of a family trying to find out who their mother truly was and why for so long they never knew about the contribution she made to science.  Skloot has a lot of disparate territory to cover in this book, including dense scientific material, but she manages with great aplomb to make \\"The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks\\" a story that is easy to understand for non-scientific folks without losing the incredibly moving aspects concerning the Lacks family.  It is a book that is hard to put down and even harder to forget.<br /><br />In 1951, Henrietta Lacks died of cervical cancer; before and after her death, doctors removed cancerous cells from her tumor-riddled body to experiment upon.  Unlike other cells that had been experimented on, Henrietta's cells were immortal - they could reproduce endlessly.  Known forever after as HeLa cells, experiments using these cells led to advancements in cancer treatments, various drugs and tests, and the Salk polio vaccine.  Yet for twenty years, her family never knew anything about the work that was being done with Henrietta's cells, and, needless to say, their world was turned upside down when they found out.  Most of her five children, if not all, lived in virtual poverty with a wide array of medical problems, unable to afford treatment and unable to understand even the basic scientific information necessary to understand what was happening with their \\"mother cells\\".<br /><br />Angry that millions had been made from HeLa cells, some family members wanted to sue Johns Hopkins to get money they thought they richly deserved; other members were happy to receive recognition of who HeLa really was.  After years of frustration and a wily con-artist, the Lacks family was hesitant to allow Skloot to research the issue.  But Skloot was different because she didn't want to know just about the cells - she wanted to know about the woman behind them, and in this book she has paid the greatest recognition that others before her, the doctors and scientists, have never paid.<br /><br />\\"The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks\\" tells many stories, some that are extremely hard to fathom in the present day, yet times were different in the 1950s.  There was still segregation and health care for poor blacks often led to unethical experimentation (like the Tuskeegee syphilis experiment).  Skloot traces the history of cell culture, including the infamous \\"immortal chicken heart\\" and the later problems of contamination caused by HeLa cells.  Her scientific research is thorough and impeccable and entirely easy to understand.  She raises tough ethical questions and explores the pressing issue of whether or not tissue experimentation can be classified as experimentation upon human beings.  It is amazing to think of all the scientific advancements that have been made because of one woman's cells.  \\"The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks\\" is an incredible story, one that justly deals with its subject but also delivers justice to a long-suffering family.about the cells - she wanted to know about the woman behind them, and in this book she has paid the greatest recognition that others before her, the doctors and scientists, have never paid.    \\"The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks\\" tells many stories, some that are extremely hard to fathom in the present day, yet times were different in the 1950s.  There was still segregation and health care for poor blacks often led to unethical experimentation (like the Tuskeegee syphilis experiment).  Skloot traces the history of cell culture, including the infamous \\"immortal chicken heart\\" and the later problems of contamination caused by HeLa cells.  Her scientific research is thorough and impeccable and entirely easy to understand.  She raises tough ethical questions and explores the pressing issue of whether or not tissue experimentation can be classified as experimentation upon human beings.  It is amazing to think of all the scientific advancements that have been made because of one woman's cells.  \\"The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks\\" is an incredible story, one that justly deals with its subject but also delivers justice to a long-suffering family.

B001VLBDD0|3.0|I just recently re-watched TERMINATOR 2:JUDGMENT DAY (1991) to try to get some understanding as to why SO MANY movie fans think that it is the best of the Terminator films and having seen it, it is worse than I thought! I was sure that I would at least think T2 was good enough to rate closely to it's predecessor T1 and boy was I mistaken! I first saw T2 back in the early 90s and it really didn't blow me away even back then. But that was more due to the fact that I had suffered sequel overload during that time (DIE HARD 2 and LETHAL WEAPON 2 being the main culprits, both of which I loved at the time and can't stand now!), but also that I was more into Arnold Schwarzenegger movies (three Arnie action classics PREDATOR-1987, RUNNING MAN-1988, and TOTAL RECALL-1990 had just come out) than I was into Terminator movies. I just wanted to see an Arnie action film! I know the Terminator is supposedly different from the typical Arnie flick, but I wasn't fully aware of this at the time. In retrospect, I understand better what the Terminator films encompass.    With T2, I kind of got an Arnie action film, but not really; it's more of a James Cameron film, which for me, is not really a good thing. I think Cameron is perhaps the most overrated director in modern film history! In T2, Arnie's T800 is really only a nominal (although above the title credits) character; and plays 2nd fiddle to Sarah Connor (played by Linda Hamilton, who overemotes mightily in this) and 10-year old John Connor (an annoying Edward Furlong) and acts as their protector from the T1000. Robert Patrick plays the T1000, whose liquid metal configuration is a cool (if unbelievable) creation. Patrick is actually pretty good in his limited screen time and definitely exudes menace, but the fear of his character is derived more from his seemingly invincible design (backed up by some incredible, groundbreaking CGI) than the actor himself. In T1, we saw Schwarzenegger's T800 bit by bit lose his \\"humanity\\" to reveal the creature underneath (with the aid of puppetry and stop-motion animation) and that was a lot scarier.    The T2 supporting cast ranges from very weak (John's foster parents, who weren't even REMOTELY curious as to why a huge German-accented leather-clad biker was looking for John!) to inconsequential (Sarah's Mexican friend that helped hide them out), but not all their fault as they aren't operating with much of a script. Also, I found myself cringing at certain scenes, and for the wrong reasons! A major example would be the poorly executed (no pun intended) \\"key\\" scene when the heroic trio go after the T800 creator Dyson: When Arnie's T800 strips off the human skin on his robotic arm to prove their story to Dyson, the bug-eyed reactions of Dyson and his wife were way over-the-top. But the worst part of that scene was Sarah's overly melodramatic crisis of conscience about killing Dyson; Hamilton's acting during that scene was really bad. Contrast an ineffectual manipulative \\"Hollywood\\" scene like this one to the more \\"naturalistic\\" character reactions in T1, which wasn't made with some studio bigwigs getting in the way of the director's vision. Also, I thought the whole Dyson subplot to be kind of tacked on.    Arnie's one-liners (which shouldn't even really exist in a movie like this) come off as mostly stale due to a painfully weak, by-the-numbers script. I couldn't believe how poor the dialogue was when I saw this again recently! Not really even an attempt at realism or humor. The dialogue serves as filler material to either try to be cute with silly catchphrases (and dated ones at that) or to pontificate unnecessarily about nuclear war and the fate of humanity. T1 didn't have such waste in it, cutting to the chase (literally) and even the expository dialogue and scenes were PART OF the action, rather than being separate from it like in T2.    James Cameron is not really one of my favorite directors (although I think T1 is perhaps the best sci-fi action film ofall time), but he did a tremendous job of helping to usher in a new era of special effects with T2 (major reason why I'm at least giving it 3 stars!). The 20-year old effects are still very eye-catching indeed and top even a lot of the current CGI in movies now. But the main problem with the effects is, as previously alluded to, with the logic behind the makeup Patrick's T1000 character. Are we supposed to accept at face value that such an unlikely creation from the not-so-distant future is even possible? Yeah, it's cool, but it's there as simply an excuse for action and to wow us with advanced effects, whereas in T1, Arnie's T800 was an actual CHARACTER! When it comes to CGI vs. character, give me character anyday!

B000OPOAM0|5.0|My title is two-fold, because not only do I think 1984's THE TERMINATOR (T1) is the best and undisputed of all the Terminator movies, I also think it's the best and undisputed of James Cameron's films! I really think that after this original classic, Cameron totally lost his ability to tell a solid story and got too caught up in special effects extravaganzas. Don't believe me? Then watch (I mean really WATCH!) the first sequel to T1, TERMINATOR 2: JUDGMENT DAY (T2). It has fantastic effects, but ZERO character development or story! It is the template for the typical, mindless summer action movies that come out in drones in today's CGI-laden film world. The characters in T2 are one-dimensional throughout and the dialogue in that movie is inane and borders on atrocious! Cameron got it right with T1.    T1 is an superb amalgamation of several genres working in perfect synergy: science fiction, horror, action, love story, AND speculation! And all this happens in an amazingly short running time, but the film doesn't feel incomplete (T2 is twice as long and feels totally incomplete!). Quite simply, T1 has \\"no fat\\" on it. Everything seems necessary to propel the plot along.     Arnold Schwarzenegger's performance is a wonder to behold to this day! I still don't think enough people appreciate how great it truly is. He is totally convincing as a machine, and nothing to do with the fact that he is an actor of limited range (ok, maybe that's part of it!). But imagine how hard it must be to literally be \\"emotionless\\", but to react not as a human would, but as a programmed machine would, and he pulled it off. Most other actors that play robots (including the ones in the sequels) tend to play it the same in an all-too obvious, monotone manner, and aren't able to hide human characteristics.     The other two main performances should not be overlooked either. Both Michael Biehn (as futuristic rebel soldier Kyle Reese) and Linda Hamilton (as Sarah Connor future mother of resistanceleader John Connor) deliver knockout performances as well. The actors really \\"sell\\" the movie and lift it to a higher level than lesser or miscast actors would have.     T1's main draw is it's claustropobic, unsettling, atmospheric, noirish tone and feel throughout, thanks in large part to the memorable beating, bouncing score that accompanies the Terminator whenever he shows up. The film's first big set piece is at the aptly named Tech Noir dance club and that scene signifies the entire mood of T1. Then the iconic \\"I'll be back\\" police station showdown puts the icing on the cake! Set mostly at night, the underlying theme of T1 is doom, dread, and hopelessness, yet the film never bores as it moves at a fast pace, has gritty dialogue, strong characters, and a pulse-pounding climax.     The undisputed, original king of the action, sci-fi genre!

B00004YRQA|5.0|Though the high price point and limited space are something of a burden,the OFFICIAL Sony PS2 memory card is a reliable product. However, ALL NEED TO WATCH OUT FOR THE BOOTLEGS ON HERE.    Here are some things I would say to examine to make sure you have a legitimate memory card.    BEFORE BUYING THE CARD  - Beware of very low prices. I would personally be suspicious of anything lower than $10.00.    - Try to ask the seller if the card you are thinking of buying from them is made in Japan. Legitimate cards are without a doubt made in Japan, so you should be   wary if they mention any place other than Japan.    - Try to read some of the negative feedback the seller has received. If you see even ONE buyer that hints that they got a questionable card, be on the defensive...    - If there's a product description entered for the card on the prices page, read it VERY carefully. Though a seller may state the card is \\"real\\", it doesn't mean it's an OFFICIAL product.  *Example of a suspect listing:  BRAND NEW CARD!! REAL!!!! BUY NOW!!!!    The listing says the card is \\"REAL\\" but it doesn't state the card is an \\"OFFICIAL\\" Sony memory card.    ************************************    IF YOU'VE ALREADY BOUGHT AND RECEIVED A CARD, DON'T OPEN IT YET!!!!! There's a few ways to tell you're dealing with an illegitimate card before you even open the package.    - Look over the packaging and see if the card was made ANYWHERE else other than Japan. If you see it was made in China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, or any other place, it may very well be a fake.    - Read EVERY WORD on the packaging that you can. This includes ALL the precautions and instructions on the back and front of the packaging. Much like a lot of unprofessional things, a spelling error is the number one clue of something low class. Even ONE spelling error is grounds for suspicion in my book...    - Look for sentences or words on the packaging that are either spaced to close or too far from each other. With a fake card that I got, there were many sentences that seemed to be written fine from afar. However, when you looked closer, the sentences had strangely high amounts of space in between them. Think of it as someone writing a sentence with an inch of space between each word....    - Look at the font of the words on the packaging. The sentences on an official card's packaging have a very crisp and clean looking font to them. However, with the card I got, the font was really ugly and cheap looking.    - Look for writing on the front of the packaging that tells you the color of the card. In the top left hand corner, there is black writing with a white background that tells you the color of the card on an official package.    - If you have one on hand, try to compare the front of the card you received with an official Sony PS2 memory card. When I compared my official cards with the fake I received, I saw that the fake had the words \\"Magicgate\\" printed very sloppily on it. That is, the words were curving upwards when they should've been perfectly straight. Think of it as how it looks when one tries to write a straight sentence on paper that doesn't have lines.    - Try to get a feel for the quality of plastic used to make the card. A card I received looked to be made out of very cheap plastic and I practically had to snap it back together since it was splitting apart.    ********************************************************    IF YOU'VE ALREADY OPENED THE PACKAGE AND ARE WONDERING IF YOU HAVE A FAKE  - Look to see if the card has varying amounts of free space on it. I've read that some cards have varying space even if nothing is saved on them.    - Pay attention to any games having a hard time saving to the card. Saving or loading data to and from the card may take long periods of time. In addition, you may encounter frequent bouts of corrupted data.    ******************************************************    There's likely many more signs of fake cards out there, but I think this is a good start of things to look for. Always make sure to take as many precautions when buying these cards as you can. The annoyance of a dysfunctional product is simply not worth the low price you may pay for it....
